text: a supermarket in Caracas empty
unhallowed many shelves have been left
empty as the country struggles to deal
with its worst economic crisis in the
last three years the economy has shrunk
by a third the government blamed us-led
sanctions but the widespread view is
that this is more the result of the
mismanagement of the country's vast oil
resources with little food and
supermarkets
it's here where Venezuelans come to find
what they need Street markets but prices
here rise fast
this farmers market is an example of
hyperinflation here that whites border
have prices which have double or triple
take some returns at the beginning of
the time areas in Caracas they were sold
for $45 bars a few weeks later this had
risen to a hundred which is a hundred
and twenty-two percent higher the same
with eggs in a matter of weeks they
became 50% more expensive passing from
32 to 48 bolivars economists say that
it's a mixture of shortages and the lack
of production from the private sector
that is affecting prices in the country
one day you find a price and the next
day is changed we have to do miracles
here I'm 92 and I have to shop around
different places to find better prices
we don't know who's in charge of this
mess but we have to eat so we have to
take this
as I was in Caracas I did manage to find
a supermarket with some food on its
shelves but this told me another story
about the country's current economy in a
country with regular shortages and
incredible levels of inflation you can
also find extraordinary distortions so
take for instance Qatar which is
regulated by the state it costs one cent
of a US dollar if you walk further down
the shelves you can find other goods
which you may not need on a regular
basis
like let's say slices of Victoria sponge
but this costs two thousand percent more
than the pasta which is regulated by the
states and then you have the supply
chain which for shops like these is
incredibly uncertain one day there are
no eggs there's no milk and another day
you can only find toilet paper in every
single shelf and shops simply don't know
what to do with it
Venezuela's inflation is already
mind-boggling
the IMF already thinks it will close
2018 above 1 million percent and next
year the IMF economists think it could
be 10 times higher
Vladimir Hernandez BBC News Caracas
